docs.lead_paragraph: Two Executives of Failed Bayou Fund Group Expected to Surrender to Authorities Today Samuel Israel III, the chief executive of the Bayou Group, the hedge fund that seemingly evaporated overnight in what federal prosecutors have described as a $300 million fraud, is expected to surrender to the federal authorities today along with the fund's chief financial officer, Daniel E. Marino. [Page C1.] Drug Agency's Criminal Unit Joins Guidant Inquiry Criminal investigators at the Food and Drug Administration have apparently become involved in the agency's inquiry into how Guidant handled problems with its heart devices, said two people contacted by the investigators. [C1.] Interest in Electric Vehicles Rekindled by High Fuel Prices The high price of gasoline is rekindling interest in electric cars. While General Motors and other manufacturers discontinued their electric vehicle programs, Mitsubishi Motors said it was developing one and Subaru plans to start testing a new prototype in March. [C1.] A Mogul Who Would Rebuild New Orleans Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans is expected to name a commission to advise him on the rebuilding of the city. Almost certain to make the grade is the real estate mogul Joseph C. Canizaro, who is perhaps the single most influential business executive in New Orleans.[C1.] Ford Offers Fire Shields for Some Lincoln Town Cars Ford Motor, acknowledging for a second time that fuel tanks in some of its large sedans pose an increased risk of explosion in rear-end collisions, offered to provide protective fire shields to owners of Lincoln Town Car stretch limousines. [C3.] Kodak Gives Near-Term Warning, Long-Term Hope The Eastman Kodak Company, which has missed its earnings targets for three quarters, said earnings were likely to be disappointing for the rest of the year. But at a three-and-a-half-hour meeting with analysts, company executives, including the chief executive, Antonio M. Perez, left, tried to assure analysts that by 2008, the digital business will be humming along, Kodak will have regained the investment grade credit rating it lost this year, and any revenue from its conventional film business will be a bonus. [C2.] Health Agency Warns of Paxil Risks During Pregnancy The popular antidepressant Paxil may increase the risk of birth defects if pregnant women take it during the first trimester, federal health officials said. [A14.] Merrill to Open Joint Banking Venture in Japan Merrill Lynch said it would join with the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, a large Japanese bank, to open a private banking joint venture catering to Japanese individuals who have more than $1 million to save or invest. The venture, which would open in the middle of next year, would be Merrill Lynch's first big push into Japan, the world's second-largest market for financial services after the United States, since the company pulled out of a failed retail brokerage business in 2001 with heavy losses. [C3.] Chevron Reports Capsized Oil Platform in Gulf Five days after Hurricane Rita made landfall, the extent of the damage to operations in the Gulf of Mexico sharpened after Chevron indicated that one of its three large platforms had capsized after losing its moorings. [C4.] Report Shows Strong Durable Goods Orders in August Orders for durable goods showed a surprisingly robust recovery in August, the government reported, indicating that the manufacturing sector was picking up pace after a sharp drop in July and before Hurricanes Katrina and Rita devastated the Gulf Coast. [C5.] Stocks End Mixed as Industrial Data Offsets Oil Gain Wall Street trading ended mixed as investors welcomed data showing a reinvigorated industrial sector but wrestled with an increase in oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.88 points, to 10,473.09. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 1.23 points, to 1,216.89. The Nasdaq composite index fell 1.02 points, to 2,115.40. [C6.] Russian Gas Giant to Buy Nation's No.5 Oil Producer Russia's government-owned natural gas giant Gazprom said it would buy Sibneft, the country's fifth-largest oil company, for $13.09 billion, further extending the Kremlin's control of major oil producers here. [C8.] New Austerity for German Auto Industry The German auto industry is embarking on a stringent belt-tightening campaign. DaimlerChrysler said that it would cut 8,500 jobs and Volkswagen said that it would build a new sport utility vehicle at its main plant in Wolfsburg after extracting a 20 percent wage reduction from its workers. [C3.]
